newsitem.title: USA: Rains benefit Florida citrus groves.
newsitem.headline: Rains benefit Florida citrus groves.

text.p: Rains throughout the citrus belt in the week ended September 1 helped to maintain most of Florida's groves, trees and new crop fruit in "very good to excellent condition," the Florida Agricultural Statistics Service (FASS) said.
"There is generally adequate surface soil moisture in all areas of the citrus belt," FASS said in its weekly release.
Most young trees still have an abundance of new growth, while older trees are showing mainly dark green mature foliage, FASS said.
Fruit sizes are average for this time of year, however Navel groves are better than average. Packing houses continued to test fruit for early picking and shipping.

FASS said caretakers are mowing, chopping and discing cover crops, while growers are herbiciding, spraying and fertilizing trees between showers. Dead tree removal and some resetting continued, they added.
